bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John H. Andrus, March 11, 1938

div1.p: Hench introduces a physician who will give Andrus medical advice. He will review Andrus' case himself after returning from Europe.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to John H. Andrus, March 11, 1938
div1.opener:
March 11, 1938
Mr. J. H. Andrus
805 Cooper St.
Camden, N. J.
My dear Mr. Andrus:
div1.p:
Your letter just arrived, to reach me at the time of very
hurried preparations for my departure for Europe to some medical meetings.
Therefore, I will have to answer you very hastily.

I read your son's and your letter with interest and I am asking
Dr. Woltman, the head of our neurological department to go over it. Please
tell your son, Dr. Andrus, that I will write him a detailed letter on my re-
turn home in about ten or twelve weeks. It is possible that arthritis may be
a very definite factor in your nerve condition but certainly you have more
profound nerve changes than the great majority of people, even with severe
arthritis of the spine. The trouble may be a bad combination of two diseases.
It is really impossible for me to say without the privilege of seeing you,
and I hesitate very greatly to put you to the bother and expense of coming
here unless we are sure that we can do something for you. Nevertheless, I
do want to see what can be done.

In the matter of the bed, I am asking one of my colleagues to make
some inquiries and he will drop you a line.

I hope you will not think I am running out on you, by writing you
so briefly, but I have been in a frenzy these last few days; hence this
hasty and short letter.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
